displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer? Doctor: Yeah. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. Family Member: I need the pharmacy to call me or go harass somebody. Patient: Good luck with that. (Laughs)

Family Member: The trial, yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll, I’ll clarify that today. Okay? As soon as we’re done. Uh, there’s two different groups I’ve got to talk to, uh, about that. Uh, then I will, uh, I’ll get that information to you as soon as I have it. And if I don’t- Family Member: But one, one of them you said that he’d get both drugs. So he’d probably want to do that one, I guess. Because one you get one and the other one you’re going to get both. You just get the- Patient: You talking about the one with the prednisone? Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. in scheduling your appointment and ask you the possible – he maybe to see this Friday. But I think if he can see you this week, than Patient: Okay. Doctor: a lot of information and try to look over that consent form. Patient: I will. Thank you. Doctor: Alright. I like this plan. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Good seeing you. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick. Patient: Well not really. Doctor: Okay, I’m just saying. Patient: You know I’m just saying doc, I doc, you know. Doctor: Yeah. That’s gonna be your decision. Okay. Family Member: Excuse me. Doctor: Yep, Yeah.

Patient: And it’s basically a high protein low carb uh kind of a program. Doctor: Ah. Patient: And so I am processing more protein. Doctor: Yep. Patient: And I believe, I believe that protein is one of the things that can drive the creatinine up. Doctor: That is true. Patient: Okay. So how do I… Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose.

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Now what’s the best way to - Doctor: Get in touch with me? So one-eight hundred_____. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And you ask them to page me. Family Member: All right. Doctor: That’s probably the best. Healthcare Professional: As a matter of fact, I’m going to go get schedule; I’ll be right back. Doctor: Easiest, in some ways, yeah. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to go get POS. Doctor: So, so I think now you’re going to - Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh -

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause)

Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early. Patient: Okay, I know. I know. Doctor: Hang in there. Patient: I try to keep that… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …here and you know I try to stay, stay busy to keep my mind away from you know how you automatically get you know. Doctor: Sure, right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Ahh to essentially sterilize the field that exposed to that… Patient: I’m sure it’s very pinpoint because my wife was over at the R ___. So, Doctor: It is, it is as precise as they can make it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s done you know the modeling that they use, the 3D mapping… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m saying that that’s um you know I’ll do that twice just so… Family Member: Okay. Patient: You know I got an appointment with you later in June does that cancel? Doctor: No we’ll cancel that because we don’t need it. Yeah don’t worry about that. (Laughs) Patient: Well I was just wondering. Doctor: Yeah we’ll figure that out. Family Member: Never mind then. Doctor: Depending on the cryo if you decide to go with that and all of that and when Dr. C____ does it, then your next appointments will be changed Patient: Yep. Doctor: according to that. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Sound like a plan?

Patient: Okay Doctor: If the shot doesn’t work out then we just have to stay very calm and either try a different shot which is a real pain in the neck shot because it’s an everyday shot for like three to four days that you would have to give yourself. Which if you can’t you would have to come here and we would give it to you, but that’s a cousin drug. Patient: Another chemo type. Doctor: No to get the white cells to remain up. Patient: Oh...Oh I see what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah remember this is a shot… Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day. Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay.
